cont.entity_a: High quality steel and heat treatment for lasting cutter edge. Hardness of steel questionable. Well made with a hardened cutting edge.
cont.entity_b: Top quality with a good grip. High quality comparable to older models.

cont.entity_a: Cuts wire with ease and is made of hefty steel. Effective at cutting trim nails and steel washers. Requires a strong grip to cut through washers. Not as good cutting force as expected. Functional for general use but not heavy duty. Durable and cuts cleanly. Blades undamaged after cutting stainless steel springs. Cuts through wire and plastic easily. Good for cutting wire and welding rods. Durable and retains sharpness after use. Not as strong as Irwin pliers for cutting wire. Not sharp enough for cutting close to a knot.
cont.entity_b: Effective for cutting heavy wire and artificial floral stems. No dents or chips after cutting tap con. Cuts flex duct wire effectively. Sharp enough to cut a single thread.

cont.entity_a: Blunt tip reduces usability in certain situations. Poor finish, with sharp edges and a tight hinge. Poor quality control with rough and sharp edges. Tight hinge requiring WD-40 for smooth operation. Poor quality with a gap at the cut edge.
cont.entity_b: Poor alignment of jaws affects cutting performance. Wide mouth and strong cutting blades. Hinge binding issue reducing usability. Ergonomically designed for easy use. Pivot design enhances leverage and reduces effort. Curved handle prevents slipping. Not insulated for cutting hot wires.

cont.entity_a: Excellent leverage for cutting. Great leverage with a longer handle.
cont.entity_b: Handles longer than older models for better leverage. Leverage and angle ideal for tight spaces.
Durable in wet conditions. Rusts quickly if exposed to water.
Ergonomically designed for easy use. Curved handle prevents slipping.

cont.entity_a: Works well but lacks refinement in finish compared to older models.
Excellent value for an American made product. Satisfactory for the price.
